Award.AwardTitle: Probing the Origins of Solar Systems with Millimeter-wave Interferometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support an observational project to obtain spatially-resolved images of nearby, gas-rich protoplanetary disks. These disks are found around stars that have an age of 1-3 million years, and are of great interest because they represent the earliest stages of the formation of planets. The project has three goals: to detect evidence of the presence of Jupiter-mass planets, which should produce gaps and asymmetries in disks; to investigate dust coagulation and fragmentation processes during the first stages of planet formation; and to measure the density and motions of the circumstellar gas in the inner disk mid-plane and explore the implications for planetary formation models.

Direct detection of planets in circumstellar disks would provide key information for the mechanisms and time scale for planet formation. This is a very active area of research, and it is anticipated that understanding the process of planet formation will reveal the conditions that led to the formation of the Earth and the solar system.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding the formation of planets and the origin of the key ingredients for life is one of the greatest challenges of modern Astronomy. Planets are ubiquitous in our Galaxy but the physical processes responsible for their formation are poorly understood. Furthermore, it is still unknown what fraction of these planets might have suitable conditions for life. Current focus regarding habitability centers primarily on measuring the atmospheric composition and temperature of planets. However, the planet formation process(es) and the characteristics of the environment in which planets form likely play a key role in setting the initial conditions suitable for life to develop. The interplay between these processes is still beyond our understanding. 

The main scientific goal of the NSF award "Probing the Origins of Solar Systems with Millimeter-wave Interferometry" was to study the physical processes responsible for the formation of planets by imaging planetary systems in the act of forming. The project PI, Dr. Isella, and collaborators achieved this goal by exploiting the unprecedented imaging capabilities of the recently constructed Atacama Large Millimeter Array (ALMA), and the recently upgraded Jansky Very Large Array (JVLA), which allowed mapping the distribution of dust particles and molecular gas around young stars detecting features as small as 1 Astronomical Unit (AU, the main distance between the Earth and the Sun). The targets of our observations were the so called "proto-planetary" disks, i.e., the primordial clouds of dust and gas that surround newborn stars and provide the reservoir material for the formation of planets. 

Intellectual merit: The images of protoplanetary disks obtained as part of this NSF award were a breakthrough in the study of planet formation. They provided the first, and long awaited, direct information on the physical processes responsible for the evolution of solids particles in protoplanetary disks and revealed the presence of planetary systems in the act of forming. Our research activities culminated with the discovery of annular rings in the distribution of dust particles and Carbon Monoxide molecules around the 5 million-years old star HD 163296 (see attached Figure). These structures are thought to be generated from the gravitational perturbations of young planets and reveal the mass and orbital radius of the perturbing planets. In this specific case, our analysis suggests the presence of three planets as massive as Saturn orbiting at 60 AU, 100 AU, and 160 AU from the central star, respectively.

The results of our studies were presented in more than 30 scientific articles published on high impact refereed journals including  Science, Physical Review Letters, Astrophysical Journal Letters, Astrophysical Journal, and Astronomy & Astrophysics. To date, the this publications received more than 500 citations.

Broader Impact:  This NSF award provided research opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students, as well as postdoctoral scholars, several of which were women and underrepresented minorities. All the graduate students supported by this award remained in academia and are currently working either as postdoctoral scholars or faculties, while most of the undergraduate students involved in our research activities are now attending graduate school in STEM. 

The scientific results obtained during this NSF award had a large impact among the broad non scientific community and were featured in several publications aimed at general public. Some notably examples are: 

  • Viewpoint: Searching for Baby Planets in a Star’s Dusty Rings, Physics.org
  • ALMA finds compelling evidence for pair of infant planets around young star, ScienceDaily
  • Astronomers Say There May Be Two Newborn Planets In Space, Morning News USA
  • Astronomers spot spiral arms swirling around a young star, offering clues to planet formation, Los Angeles Times
